title: 112_hr6040
content: The Act is titled the "Continued Free Association with Palau Act of 2012" and amends Title I of Public Law 99-658 by adding a section for the 15th-anniversary review agreement. The Agreement between the United States and the Republic of Palau, signed in 2010, is approved with exceptions and subject to certain provisions. Funding provisions include infrastructure maintenance and a fiscal consolidation fund. The Agreement between the United States and Palau, signed in 2010, includes provisions for infrastructure maintenance, a fiscal consolidation fund, and approval of amendments to Compact subsidiary agreements by Congress. The Agreement between the United States and Palau, signed in 2010, includes provisions for infrastructure maintenance, a fiscal consolidation fund, and approval of amendments to Compact subsidiary agreements by Congress. Years 2011 through 2016 shall be provided in fiscal years 2012 through 2017. Congress consents to amendments to the Compact subsidiary agreements. Authorization of appropriations for postal services related to Palau, the Federated States of Micronesia, and the Marshall Islands is provided for fiscal years 2012 through 2024. The Department of the Interior can transfer funds to the United States Postal Service for mail to Palau, the Federated States of Micronesia, and the Marshall Islands. Appropriations to Federal entities under the Compact of Free Association can continue through fiscal year 2024. Section 236 of the Compact applies to commitments under the Compact Review Agreement. The United States commits to funding audits and oversight for Palau under the Compact Review Agreement. Congress deems Palau eligible for certain U.S. domestic programs. The Secretary of the Interior must submit an annual report to specific Congressional committees regarding financial assistance under the Compact. The Secretary of the Interior must submit an annual report to specific Congressional committees regarding the use and effectiveness of financial, technical, and other assistance provided to Palau under U.S. domestic programs. SEC. 3. OFFSETS. Repeal of prior authorization for civil administration of Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands and limitation on use of funds for global health programs under the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961. SEC. 136. LIMITATION ON USE OF FUNDS. None of the funds for global health activities from fiscal year 2012 to 2024 can be used for assistance to China. The total amount for global health activities is reduced by $2,000,000 each fiscal year. This section applies regardless of any other laws enacted after its enactment. ``(a) Limitation.--Funds for climate change activities from 2012 to 2024 cannot be used for assistance to China. The total amount for these activities is reduced by $4,500,000 each fiscal year. This section applies regardless of any other laws enacted after its enactment. (d) Prohibition on Funding for Development Innovation Ventures (DIV) Program.--Funds for 2012 and 2013 to USAID cannot be used for the DIV program or any successor program.`` ``(c)(1) None of the funds for fiscal years 2012 and 2013 to USAID can be used for the DIV program or any successor program. (2) The total amount obligated by USAID for a fiscal year is $28,200,000 less than the total amount available for that fiscal year. (3) This applies regardless of any other laws enacted after this subsection. (e) IMET.--Section 542 of the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 is amended to limit funds for assistance to Argentina from 2012 through 2024.'' "(b) Limitation on Use of Funds.-- None of the funds for fiscal year 2012 and beyond through 2024 can be used to assist Argentina. The total amount obligated under this chapter for a fiscal year is $4,500,000 less than the total amount available. This subsection applies regardless of any other laws enacted after its enactment. (f) UNESCO.-- A new section is added to the Foreign Assistance Act of 1961 regarding UNESCO." "SEC. 308. LIMITATION ON USE OF FUNDS." The text chunk outlines limitations on the use of funds for United States contributions to the United Nations and the United States Institute of Peace. For fiscal years 2012 through 2024, funds for UNESCO contributions are restricted, and a reduction in funds for UN contributions is specified. Additionally, there is a limitation on funds for the United States Institute of Peace for the same fiscal years. The text chunk specifies a limitation on the total amount of funds that can be obligated for fiscal years 2012 through 2024, reducing the amount available for United States contributions to the United Nations and the United States Institute of Peace.
